title: What are the main differences in utilitarianism and kantianism? - Quora

response.answer_text: Am kind of astounded by all the wishy-washy answers to this question. The answer is that Utilitarianism is obviously better. If Kant would be asked by a bunch of SS Nazi officers whether he is hiding jews in his basement then he would tell them which is obviously and ridiculously wrong. Kant is an incompetent snake oil salesman hiding behind sophistry and nearly incomprehensible, needlessly complicated German sentences. (I read some of Kant in German, it’s horrible. The guy fails completely to communicate relatively simple ideas) Also, people don’t really seem to get Utilitarianism, they always interpret it in a dumb and naive way, making it seem intuitively wrong. Let’s take an example: Imagine you live in a society where it would be legal to extract the organs of (i.e. sacrifice) one healthy person to save five people (who have different organs failing). How would Utilitarianism handle this situation? Now, the naive, superficial, psychopath-Utilitarian would say “That is a good system because you save five people and only lose one so we have net utility of 5–1=four people.” That’s bullshit. Imagine a society with such a system. People would be anxious and fear for their lives all the time. That’s *huge* systemic negative utility far outweighing the utility gained from the saved lives that would result from living under that crazy law. It’s not just the quantity of human lives but also the quality of them; life is supposed to be good. Utilitarianism all the way.

Well, that question actually doesn’t make a lot of sense, and I’m explaining why. How do we define what is better and what is worse? Or, more generally, how do we define what is good and what is bad? Usually, it’s a pretty subjective decision. I mean, you like what you like for whatever reason of yours. You also think that something is right while something else is wrong because your heart says so, and no one can proof that you are objectively mistaken. Of course, seeking to decrease arbitrariness, misuse of power, and to make it possible for different people to peacefully coexist, we developed systems that can uniform this sort of judgement. So that we have standardized logical processes, which we can use to evaluate what is better, in an “unbiased” fashion. But the problem here is that there even when it comes to these systems, there are many of them, and we can’t say that any of them is “better” in an absolute sense. As a matter of fact, whether you do prefer Utilitarianism or Kantianism, you are going to arbitrarily choose which criteria for defining what’s good and bad is the “best” one (whatever that means for you). Therefore, if you’re an utilitarian, and you use the utilitarian metric, then you can argue that Utilitarianism is “better”, because it delivers what utilitarianism defines as “good” more efficiently. On the other side, Kantianism is obviously better from a kantianist perspective. So, this discussion ends up being pretty nonsensical, and this we can claim objectively.
